front.title: Deployment Considerations for In-situ OAM with IPv6 Options

postal.street: Cessna Business Park, Sarjapura Marathalli Outer Ring Road

abstract.t: In-situ Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (IOAM) records operational and telemetry information in the packet while the packet traverses a path between two points in the network. This document outlines how IOAM data fields are encapsulated in IPv6.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In-situ Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (IOAM) records operational and telemetry information in the packet while the packet traverses a path between two points in the network. defines how IOAM data fields are encapsulated in the IPv6 . This document discusses deployment options for networks which leverage IOAM data fields encapsulated in the IPv6 protocol.
Deployment considerations differ, whether the IOAM domain starts and ends on hosts or whether the IOAM encapsulating and decapsulating nodes are network devices that forward traffic, such as routers.

section.title: IOAM encap in v6
section.t: IOAM data is carried in IPv6 packets as Hop-by-Hop or Destination options. One IPv6 Destination Options and Hop-by-Hop Options Type codepoint is assigned for IOAM. Multiple options with the same Option Type MAY appear in the same Hop-by-Hop Options or Destination Options header, with varying content. This mechanism of in-situ OAM in IPv6 is used to enhance diagnostics of IPv6 networks. It complements other mechanisms proposed to enhance diagnostics of IPv6 networks, such as the IPv6 Performance and Diagnostic Metrics Destination Option described in .

All the in-situ OAM IPv6 options defined here have alignment requirements. Specifically, they all require 4n alignment. This ensures that 4 octet fields specified in such as transit delay are aligned at a multiple-of-4 offset from the start of the Hop-by-Hop Options header. In addition, to maintain IPv6 extension header 8-octet alignment and avoid the need to add or remove padding at every hop, the Trace-Type for Incremental Tracing Option in IPv6 MUST be selected such that the IOAM node data length is a multiple of 8-octets.

section.title: IOAM domains bounded by hosts
section.t: For deployments where the IOAM domain is bounded by hosts, hosts will perform the operation of IOAM data field encapsulation and decapsulation. IOAM data is carried in IPv6 packets as Hop-by-Hop or Destination options, see .

section.title: IOAM domains bounded by network devices
section.t: For deployments where the IOAM domain is bounded by network devices, network devices such as routers form the edge of an IOAM domain. Network devices will perform the operation of IOAM data field encapsulation and decapsulation.

section.title: Approach
section.t: Leverage an IP-in-IPv6 approach: Preserve the original IP packet and add an IPv6 header including IOAM data fields in an extension header in front of it, to forward traffic within and across the IOAM domain. The overlay network formed by the additional IPv6 header with the IOAM data fields included in an extension header is referred to as IOAM Overlay Network (ION) in this document. IPv6 addresses for the ION, i.e. the outer IPv6 addresses are assigned from the ULA space. Addressing and routing in the ION are to be configured so that the IP-in-IPv6 encapsulated packets follow the same path as the original, non-encapsulated packet would have taken.

section.title: Domain Interior Routes/Prefixes
section.t: For each IP route/prefix interior to the IOAM domain (i.e. hosts have addresses from these prefixes) a corresponding /128 route from the ION address space is allocated on every IOAM encapsulating/decapsulating router with the same metric and associated interface. When a host originated packet arrives at an IOAM encapsulating router, the destination address of the packet is looked up to find the corresponding /128 internal ION route. The encapsulating IOAM router imposes an IPv6 header on the packet and uses the retrieved /128 matching route as destination address. The IPv6 address of the encapsulating router is used as the source address. The encapsulating router also includes an IPv6 extension header to carry IOAM data fields, per . The original IP packet follows the new IPv6 extension header without any modification. This means that the ION route/prefix can be understood as an internal routeable index or proxy for the destination address/prefix of the original packet.

Based on the above configuration of prefixes on its interfaces, router X automatically generates and announces into the IGP (or BGP with no export community) matching ION internal /128s routes for each of them, using addresses from the ULA space mentioned above. This example uses fd1f:d2:feed::/48. The corresponding ION /128s for IOAM Router X's interfaces would be:

When a packet enters the IOAM domain at IOAM Router Z, with a destination address that falls within 2001:db8:0:1234::/64 (Router X's interface A prefix), the outer tunnel header's destination address would be the corresponding fd1f:d2:feed::1234/128 (Router X's intf A: ION /128 prefix). This encapsulated packet should follow the same path through the IOAM domain that a packet destined towards 2001:db8:0:1234::/64 should, from IOAM Router Z to IOAM Router X, because 2001:db8:0:1234::/64 and fd1f:d2:feed::1234/128 prefixes have both the same origin router and the same path metrics.

If another packet enters the IOAM domain at IOAM Router Z, with a destination address that falls within 2001:db8:0:4567::/64 (IOAM Router X intf C's second prefix), then the outer packet tunnel destination address would be the corresponding fd1f:d2:feed::4567/128 (Router X interface C's second and matching ION /128 prefix). As the metric for 2001:db8:0:4567::/64 and fd1f:d2:feed::4567/128 on Router X is 150, the path through the IOAM domain between IOAM Router Z and IOAM Router X for this packet could be different to the one taken in the previous example.

For completeness, for a different Router Y, with a destination address that falls within 2001:db8:0:3456::/64 (Router X intf C's first prefix), then the outer packet tunnel destination address would be the corresponding fd1f:d2:feed::3456/128 (Router X intf C's first and matching ION /128 prefix).

section.title: Domain Exterior Routes/Prefixes
section.t: For exterior routes, IPv6-in-IP tunnelling is used in a similar way. Transit across the ION follows the transit approach for traffic between BGP border routers, as described in RFC1772, "A.2.3 Encapsulation". In addition to the new IPv6 outer header, an IPv6 extension header carrying the IOAM data fields would be added.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document describes the encapsulation of IOAM data fields in IPv6. Security considerations of the specific IOAM data fields for each case (i.e., Trace, Proof of Transit, and E2E) are described in defined in .
